results.title: You can do anything
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Film Australia and Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training
results.brief_description: The Kirinara Hostel in N.S.W. offers an educational program specifically designed for young Aboriginal and Islander people. The video focuses on students at the hostel and includes interviews with ex-students who have pursued careers in a diverse range of fields including law, teaching, football and dance. The graduates stress the importance of individuals setting realistic goals for themselves as well as the need for Aboriginal education support schemes to assist young Aboriginal people to achieve their full educational potential.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aviva Ziegler, Film Australia and Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training

results.title: You can count on me
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Lonergan, John N. Hart, Larry Meistrich, Jeffrey Sharp, Barbara de Fina, Hart Sharp Entertainment, Cappa Productions and Shooting Gallery
results.brief_description: You can count on me is a family reunion drama that contains impressive performances full of nuance and has an adroit observational tone. The original screenplay (by director Kenneth Lonergan) veers away from cliche and pat conclusions, imbuing the characters with a realistic quality. Sammy and Terry are orphaned at a young age when their parents are killed in a car accident. As adults, the siblings are estranged, having made divergent choices. Sammy is a single parent with an eight-year-old son, Rudy, living in the house she was brought up in, working in a bank. She lives by a strict moral code, bound by religion and duty, but is entirely capable of hypocrisy and self-delusion. Terry, by contrast, is a wild loner, full of rage, self-destructive by nature but charming in his own humorous way. He doesn’t believe in Sammy’s ordered conservative life and inadvertently challenges this, creating chaos with his presence. It is Terry and Rudy’s strengthening relationship that acts as a catalyst, causing an irrevocable torrent of truths that upend the family dynamics. The personal and familial dilemmas contained within the script are identifiable and the film sensitively deals with themes of oppression and personal choice. Cast includes: Laura Linney, Matthew Broderick, Mark Ruffalo, Rory Culkin.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kenneth Lonergan, John N. Hart, Larry Meistrich, Jeffrey Sharp, Barbara de Fina, Hart Sharp Entertainment, Cappa Productions and Shooting Gallery

results.title: You can always go higher
results.creator_credit: Frank Chalmers, Chris Carroll, Queensland. Dept. of Education and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: This video explains the Aboriginal and Islander Tertiary Aspirations Program (AITAP) and how it can help Aboriginal and Islander people achieve a tertiary education.

results.title: You can't take it with you
results.brief_description: Meet the Vanderhofs - the zaniest, happiest family ever to grace the screen. They have a simple philosophy for living “Nothing is worth doing if you can’t enjoy it - and when it’s over you can’t take it with you”. Head of this eccentric clan is Grandpa, (Lionel Barrymore) who has decided to devote the rest of his life to having fun because he has enough money. Matters become complicated when his granddaughter (Jean Arthur) falls in love with James Stewart, son of a tycoon (Edward Arnold), who wants the Vanderhof property to expand his business. Wholesome, homespun, appealing and touching this screwball Capra comedy won two Academy Awards in 1938 for Best Picture and Best Direction.

results.title: You Can't Say That
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Oh! The problems of censorship! John Baxter shows, from the days of seemingly innocuous material such as the Keystone Cops to the present, that there have been recurrent problems with Censorship boards. This program, part of a ten part documentary, Filmstruck, considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: You can't grow potatoes up there
results.creator_credit: Peter Crass and North West Territories Information
results.brief_description: Illustrates the importance of seal hunting in the traditional life of the Inuit Eskimo of Canada’s Arctic. Made on location with three groups of Inuit hunters, the films hows how their traditional existence has become dangerously threatened by anti-sealing publicity. Hunters show the different techniques used to hunt seal year round; the use that is made of the meat; and how the skins are prepared for sale.

results.title: You can't always tell
results.creator_credit: Scott Hicks, Terry Jennings and Chrysalis Films
results.brief_description: This film aims to inform children in the seven to twelve age group of the problem of child molesting. It contains a series of dramatised scenes showing situations in which children can find themselves. Shows children how to avoid putting themselves at risk with strangers.

results.title: You are what you eat
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nutrition”.
Six lively programs hosted by Liza Goddard which offer information and practical advice on how to dramatically improve health by altering eating habits. Although aimed at British adults the programs are short and pacy and very relevant to Australian adolescents and adults. The contents are: “Food for life: how to include more fibre, fruit, vegetables and fish”, “Go with the grain: re-educating children to eat more grain”, “Don’t eat your heart out: reducing fats in the diet”, “Sweet nothing: try to eliminate sugar which provides no nourishment”, “Pinch of chemicals: manufactured goods contain additives, preservatives and salt”, “Food in the fast lane: simple suggestions for nourishing packed lunches and fast foods”.
